Executive Summary

Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act Amendments requires EPA to publish regulations and guidance for chemical accident prevention at facilities that use certain hazardous substances. These regulations and guidance are contained in the Risk Management Plan (RMP) rule.  The RMP rule requires facilities that use extremely hazardous substances to develop a Risk Management Plan which:



?    identifies the potential effects of a chemical accident,

?    identifies steps the facility is taking to prevent an accident, and

?    spells out emergency response procedures should an accident occur.



Oxy Permian (OXY) owns and operates the Indian Basin Gas Plant (IBGP), a natural gas processing plant located in Eddy County, Lakewood City, New Mexico.  . This report provides the supporting documentation for the 5 year RMP renewal submittal.



The IBGP extracts natural gas liquids (NGLs), produces sweet residue gas for sales, and manufactures sweet fuel gas for plant and field consumption. The plant processes several regulated flammable substances in excess of their threshold quantities (e.g. methane, ethane, propane, butane, pentane).  These substances are listed in Tables 3-4 of the 40 CFR 68.130. This facility does not have any regulated toxic substances with an amount greater than the threshold quantity specified in 40 CFR 68.130.



For the assessed worst-case release scenario, the single vessel with the greatest amount held is the NGL Storage Vessel (PV-14.32-1902).  Considering the current administrative controls in place, this vessel's maximum held inventory is 143,200 pounds.  The following table contains a summary of the mixture composition for the maximum held inventory.

The endpoint distance for the assessed worst-case release scenario is less than the distance to public recep

tor.



For the last 5 years, the IBGP has not had an accidental release of a regulated substance where exposure to the substance, its reaction products, overpressure generated by an explosion involving the substance, or radiant heat generated by a fire involving the substance led to any of the offsite:

o    Death;

o    Injury; or

o    Response or restoration activities for an exposure of an environmental receptor.



Emergency response drills have been coordinated with local planning and response organizations.



IBGP is subject to OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM).  As such, the facility has a PSM program that includes all 14 elements of PSM.  The facility has a mechanical integrity program which includes documenting inspections, maintenance and testing of all covered equipment. Through this and other practices (e.g. Management of Change, Safe Work Permit, Pre-Start-Up Safety Reviews, Training), IBGP works towards preventing accidental releases of regulated substances.



IBGP has a written emergency response plan that includes specific actions to be taken in response to accidental releases of the regulated substances present at the facility.  It also includes information on how to contact the public and local emergency response agencies.



Regarding safety, IBGP is constantly looking for continuous improvement opportunities.

RMP Requirements

All facilities subject to the RMP rule must complete a hazard assessment analysis for the regulated chemical. In addition, the recent (5 - year) accident history and emergency response plan must be reviewed. Based on these assessments, the facility will be classified within one of three program levels.



?    Program 1 - no offsite receptor impacted (potentially and in last five years)

?    Program 2 - offsite impacts and not subject to Occupational Safety and Health Administration Process Safety Management Standard (OSHA PSM)

?    Program 3 - offsite impacts and subject to OSHA PSM



All programs require submittal of an RMP. For

Program 2 and 3 processes, two additional tasks are required:  a release prevention program and an emergency response program. The following sections provide a brief summary of the hazard assessment, accident history, prevention program, emergency response, and subsequent RMP program level determination for the IBGP facility.



Hazard Assessment

The storage tanks area was identified as having the largest potential impact, should a release / spill occur. The rupture of one tank was identified to be the worst-case release scenario since it will result in the largest spill surface area. Simultaneous rupture of the two tanks is not required within the scope of the hazard assessment, as these are totally separate vessels, and the rupture of one tank would not facilitate the rupture of the other tank. For the worst-case release scenario, the maximum distance to the level of concern is 0.4 miles. 



Receptors Impacted

Once the impact distance of the worst-case release scenario is examined, the impact on off-site receptors must be considered. If public receptors or environmental receptors are impacted, additional analysis is required. The distance from the storage tanks to the fence line is approximately 185 ft. (0.04 miles). Therefore, the level of concern (0.4 miles) extends past the fence line to off-site locations, and any unrestricted areas within this region must be evaluated to determine if public or environmental receptors are impacted. There are no environmental receptors within the impact radius. 



Accident History

There are no accidents to report for either the five year accident history (40 CFR ?68.42) or for determining Program 1 applicability (40 CFR ?68.10(b)(1)).



Emergency Response

A facility emergency response plan for the IBGP facility is in place and has been coordinated with local emergency planning and response organizations as required by 40 CFR ?68.10(b)(3).



Program Level

This facility classifies as a Program Level 1 since in the case

of a worst case release scenario the other property located within the 0.4 miles radius distances from the NGL Storage Vessel is a warehouse facility that also belongs to OXY Permian. It is important to clarify that this property is currently in compliance with OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR ?1910.19). Based on the definitions presented under section 1.2, these conditions are not compatible with Program Level 3 or Program Level 2.



Risk Management Plan Certification



Based on the criteria in 40 CFR 68.10, the distance to the specified endpoint for the worst-case accidental release scenario for the following process(es) is less than the distance to the nearest public receptor: NGL Storage Vessel.



The process is subjected to the OSHA process safety management standard in the risk management program rule (40CFR 68.10(d)(2)). The process will fall under the Program Level 1 eligibility. (40CFR 68.10(c)).



In the event of fire, explosion, or a release of a regulated substance from the process(es), entry within the distance to the specified endpoints may pose a danger to public emergency responders. Therefore, public emergency responders should not enter this area except as arranged with the emergency contact indicated in the RMP.
